transcript.content: Coldplay and “In My Place” on XFM 104.9. I’m Ricky Gervais, with me Steve Merchant.
Hello there. Lovely to be here.
Karl Pilkington there, pressing the buttons.
How long can you maintain it?
Yeah, already bored of doing it.
Every week you start it the same way.
That was not bad, though. You, actually, grammatically made sense, which is--
A rare treat, indeed, for Ricky Gervais.
Yeah. Um… some of the, uh, listeners have already worked out I’ve got nothing to say at all.
We were- we did come in a half hour early to prepare, but, instead, me and Karl were playing- you had to flick the football into the bin--
You had five goes each or the world was going to end.
That took up a good twenty-five minutes.

Yeah. I liked it when we came back and then we started just trying to beat each other in the corridor and I beat him. I scored a goal and he was gutted cause he thought he fancied himself a footballer and I beat him. Um, and I was knackered and sweating.
Um, and, uh, as I walked back to you about five minutes ago, you were looking through the records, you went, and this was lovely, you went, “Well, we've done the preparation, then.”
Yeah. Like a teenager, like an annoyed teenager whose parents have embarrassed him once again.
Cause you’re not- I mean, you’re not particularly--
I’m not good at football, no.
Well, you’re not particularly nimble on your feet.
No, you’re not. Douglas Bader is, um, more nimble.
I’m alright, I’m alright. But it- Karl’s, sort of, I think has got more skills than me, but he hasn’t got the aggression and the weight.
So I just pushed him aside.
Yeah, I’m not here next week. What are you going to do, Karl? Are you going to do the best of or something next week, aren’t ya?
Yeah, that’s what we got to sort out.
Well, we can’t sort it out. I’ve literally- I’ve got to get to the airport after this.
No, no, straight after this show you’ve got to do some links.
No, I’m not doing any links! I said I wouldn’t, so…
No we didn’t. I said I’d do some during the show and then you--
I-I-I honestly can’t do it today, so we’ll do some during the show. What are you going to do, just put the shows that we’ve done this year?
Sorry guys, uh, hate to interrupt. This is the sort of stuff we should have been discussing when you were playing football.
I know. Play a reco- what are you going to- play, play a record.
Let’s have a little bit of Foo Fighters.
Let’s just discuss this off air.
Foo Fighters, there. “Learning to Fly.” Steve, I hope the pilot that I get today flying the plane that I'm going on holiday in has already learnt to fly.
Oh ho ho! Well done. That is dynamite. That’s text--that’s a textbook link.
That’s genius. Oh, very good. Where are you going? Wha-what’s the story? Where are you off to?
What are you like on holiday? Are you a nightmare? Are you the, like--

Cause you’re quite- but you’re quite, I mean, obviously I, you know, I’ve often said on the radio before, that I- I mean, spending any length of time with you is-is one of the most unbearable things I’ve ever had to do.
I mean, spending a week with you is nightmarish. And sharing any kind of accommodation is, do you know what I mean? No seriously, it’s like, it’s like hell.
It’s like a living hell. It’s like having a teenager, it’s like having a, sort of, teenage kid who can’t, can’t be entertained by anything.
You just chill out, dude? Just max relax?
Yeah, sure, sure. And do you- and so if you’re in somewhere, like Italy, somewhere like that, cause obviously a very beautiful city and very cultured and stuff--
Is that, yeah, is that something do you enjoy? Do you enjoy the culture of that, the beautiful architecture that’s there.
As long as it’s room service and a nice room and board and it’s nice weather--
And I need to blame someone.
And is it true that you go- cause you go to Italy most years, don’t you? Is that because that’s the only food you like eating?
I like, I like pasta and pizza, yeah.

And, uh, I’ve been to other places. I went to France once and the- you can’t explain to them to cook it properly, just cook it properly. I don’t want any- “Cook it! There’s blood in the middle of that.”
Hungary there was- it was just- ohh. I went there for a while and I didn’t know- I couldn’t identify the animals--
They were killing for me. So, and I know quite a lot about natural history--
And I couldn’t identify what was on the plate. So I--
Came home early after a couple of days?
No, I just got annoyed and I-I went to McDonald’s.
Yeah. Well, that’s the great thing about McDonald’s is they are in most major cities.
Exactly. No, I-I- you can’t go wrong with pasta and pizza.
So, if we were to go on holiday and, you know, we were hanging out or whatever.
And I, um, took you to, say, a beautiful cathedral. Is that something you’d enjoy? I can’t quite imagine you actually taking the time to--
Well, as long, as long as it’s not a very long walk, you don’t have to stay there more than a couple of minutes, then I’d love to look around these places.
Right. So you would, you’d look at the cathedral--
That’s taken, you know- that takes people breathes, you know, takes people's breathes away.
You know, people travel from around the world to see that. You would- and how long would you stay--
I don’t think people travel around to see it, I think they go somewhere and they go, “Well, we might as well go see (Ricky mumbles). They’re huge.”
Would you- and would you, uh, would you, sort of, spend any time looking at that? Would you just, sort of, soak in the atmosphere for a moment or would you--
I’d look at it and I’d go, “That’s brilliant” and then if there was any sort of soaking in, I could do that later when there’s nothing to look at.
You’re memory of it, later, when you’re in the bar.
Yeah. Yeah, you can, sort of, you know--
And would you- and so- can, can you be, kind of, in awe of something like that?
Yeah. Well, if it’s big, I can. If I go into a cathedral and it’s, and it’s- I’ve seen bigger, I go, “Ohh, I’ve seen bigger.” If it’s the biggest one I’ve seen, I go, “That is huge…. let’s go.”
Sure, because you are, you’re the sort of man that’s bored and this is true, Karl. You may not be familiar with this. Ricky Gervais is a man who gets bored drinking a glass of water.

It’s-it’s absolute bor- the only thing I- Jane’s got me on to fizzy water, which at least got something there and I only drink that when I’m, sort of, dehydrated in the middle of the night. I never- there’s no- I never drink a drink of water.
Yeah, yeah. But that’s why you’ve always got headaches and you’re always--
Moaning and stuff. And that’s one of the- another one of the reasons I hate you.
But- I don’t want to say hate, I don’t mean I hate you. I didn’t mean to- I didn’t meant to blur it out that strongly!
But what I mean is if I’m spending a lot of time with you I grow to hate you.

Once, right, I said- we were in the BBC canteen and I, sort of, like- and he just put his knife and fork and said, “I’m never eating with you again.” I said, “What’s the matter?” He said, “You annoy me. You- I hate eating with you. It annoys me. You- it looks like a child food. You eat chips and sausage and rubbish. You don’t eat- look at you. You don’t touch your vegetables, you don’t drink water.” He said- he really got annoyed!
I was because you-you-you’ve got this, like, this hatred of anything that’s good for you. You won’t eat any form of salad… You just--
Because it is good for you! You need it!
Lettuce is boring! Lettuce is absolutely boring. Um, uh, cucumber are boring, you know.

But-but, yeah, but the thing is, you see, I admit that lettuce and cucumber have not that much flavor, but that’s why people will add, say, in Italy they’ll add a lovely dressing. Maybe some olive oil, maybe some balsamic vinegar.
Well, you’ve embarrassed yourself because the good thing about a nice, mature lump of cheddar cheese is you don’t have to have any dressing.
Well, though, you add some anyway.
I put a little bit of olive oil in it and maybe some mayonnaise.
Maybe some, uh, Thousand Island Dressing.
On a Ritz cracker, you don’t need it, it’s just extra.
Sure, sure. Well, good luck. I noticed you’re wearing- is this your traveling gear? You’ve got your sweatpants and the t-shirt, the free t-shirt.
Looking to get an upgrade, are you?
Song: Badly Drawn Boy- Spitting in the Wind
Badly Drawn Boy, “Spitting in the Wind” on XFM 104.9. I’m Ricky Gervais--
Are you going to be taking in any of the, uh, culture in Italy? Is that something you do?
I’d love to see you at the opera.
Don’t know about the opera. I’ve never been to the opera. I do like, uh, you know, a bit of opera.
Not- I wouldn’t sit through a whole one, but I mean, I like, I like the songs they take from it for that “World Cup” one.
And those two fat birds, what they sung in “Shawshank Redemption” was good.
But, um, I think I- you know, I haven’t gotten into it extensively. I haven’t studied the art.
Also, it’s in foreign so you don’t really know what’s happening.
What about- are you, are you a fan of any of the great English operas? Like, um, “The Pirates of Penzance?”
Yeah, Gilbert and Sullivan. To me, Gilbert and Sullivan were like the, probably, their-their day equivalent of, like, Richard Stilgoe getting together with Tony Slattery.
And then, a hundred years later, people go, “It’s brilliant.” It-it is like- they might as well, um, I don’t know, make any, any episode of “Whose Line is it Anyway?”--
Into an opera and in two hundred years time, people’ll be going, “That’s genius.”
“Listen to this one. Look, this is ‘Party Quirks.’”
Yeah, Amdram society staging “World’s Worst Step.”
Cause I- but I was, when I was in “Pirates of Penzance” once, in an amateur production--
You used to like “Whose Line is it Anyway!”
Although, I did watch it when it first came on Channel 4 fifteen, twenty years ago.

But we, um, we did “The Pirates of Penzance” when I was in an amateur dramatic society in Bristol, uh, the Bristol Operatic Society. I don’t know why I was involved, cause I can’t sing. My audition, right, this was how desperate they were for blokes. I swear to God, right, I can’t sing, you--

Yeah. Alright, calm down. And, um, I, uh, I went in and they said, “What are you going to sing?” I went, “Uh, well, I’ll just- I-I want to surprise you.” They said, “Do you want a piano accompaniment?” I said, “No, I don’t think so.”
So, I went to the back, I swear to God, I went to the back of the room and I just sang-

Steve sings “Thumbelina, Thumbelina, tiny little thing/ Thumbelina dance, Thumbelina sing/ Thumbelina, what's the difference if you're very small?/ Coz when your heart is full of love, you're six feet tall!”

I just did that and they just looked at me like I was the weirdest freak they’d ever had. Immediately put me in the chorus cause that’s how desperate they were for blokes. We staged- we rehearsed it, I couldn’t remember the lyrics.
But I couldn’t, um, I-I couldn’t remember the lyrics for--
What was it for? Was it Gilbert and Sullivan?
It was- it was “The Pirates of Penzance.”

There weren’t enough blokes, right, so the- we had to double up. So some of the pirates had to double up as the policemen who are chasing the pirates. Little bit problematic in the scene when the policemen and the pirates have a fight!

That was a little bit tricky. And the worst thing- there’s a sequence where, like, the-the-the daughters of the Major-General all kind of, like, “Oh, beautiful-” Something like, you know, um, “Oh, beautiful little girls are we, la la la la la la la.” And the women they had, they must have all been over forty. I mean, real, kind of--
Is it the sort of women that buy one of those, sort of, porcelain dolls--
And go, “Look, I’ve had a baby.” “It’s not real.” “It is a real baby! I'm gunna stab, you!?”
Exactly. It’s the sort of women you’d see maybe on TV’s “Bargain Hunt.”

You know, the kind of contestants you get on there. Those sort of women who-who sort of very in Amdram, they think they’ve come on to their looks, but they’d have never made it in-in, uh- the guy who was playing the, uh- there’s a guy who’s supposed to be an eighteen year old prince, an eighteen year old pirate, uh, the pirate king. He must have been forty, if he was a day. He also directed the show, though, so he got to prance around in these thigh-high boots. Ludicrous, it was so embarrassing. It was shameful, really.
I’d love to go to Amdram.
Amdram is a whole other world. It’s just such an incredible place cause there’s so much backbiting and envy and--
Oh, it’s incredible! I mean, it’s worse than the real world of theater and TV. It’s unbelievable cause the same old people get to do it every year cause they can hold a note.
You would absolutely adore it, Gervais. It is--
Just film it. A secret camera. Have you ever done anything in a play, Pilk?
We know this. Karl, you-you’ve performed--
I just did the, uh, a talent show, didn’t I?
Oh, tell ’em about the talent show, yeah.
Remind us of the talent show.
Uh… that’s when I did, uh, “Walk Like an Egyptian” dressed up as a woman.
And I did me magic trick.
Oh, that’s the- it’s an egg.
What was the egg one, again?
When I, uh, actually, I’ve ruined it now, saying “the egg one.” But I went onstage with, like, an hanky--
And I said, uh- at this point I was dressed up as a caretaker, innit.
I stood there with this, uh, with this hanky over me hand--
And I said, “Right, you’re going to love this one.”
I said, “I’m going to make a bird appear in front of ya, in front of ya eyes.” Right?
And they’re all like, “Ooh, god what’s he gonna do?” So, I’m stood there--
Had an egg. I said, “Oh, it hasn’t been born yet.”
They went wild for it, did they? Round of applause?
How old were you? Is that when you were, like, seventeen?
Was that- apart from, apart from your paper round, was that the high point of your life, so far?
No, I didn’t really want to do it.
Karl, I’d like to see you take that on the road.
Or maybe at least to the Edinburgh Festival next year.

Karl, we’re going to play a song now, right? One of my- a great track, “Watch That Man” off one of my favorite albums, “Aladdin Sane” by David Bowie. But, during that, can you- can you think of a couple of things for me? What’s the best thing that’s ever happened to you? Can you, can you think about that for three minutes? Me and Steve will leave you alone. Just the best thing that’s ever happened to you. Remembering everything that is amazing. Yeah? Can you do that?
“Watch That Man,” David Bowie. Steve’s caught unaware there, just wandering around. Not quite ready, were ya?
Well, no, I’m just relaxed, you know, I’m just laid back, just hanging.
Best things that ever happened to ya? Best event, best day in your life?
I mean, there’s-there’s loads of things that happen. Like, uh--
No, but do you know what I mean? You can go for obvious stuff, like, you know, meeting Suzanne--
Sticking with her an’ all that.
But take-take-take that, take that as read.
Yeah. You’ve got that on your desert island, that’s already done.
And the day, you know, you got your qualifications through.
Um, probably… I mean, when you asked me then, the first thing that came into me mind, right, that was a real surprise, right, cause it’s like you get surprises on your birthday an’ that, don’t you?
But they’re not really surprises cause you’re hassling your mum and dad for stuff--
And then they, you know, they might buy it ya.
So it’s not really a real surprise, is it? Do you know what I mean?

Uh, so I’d say something that was really like, “Oh, yeah, nice one. I’ve got something here.” is the time when me dad said, “Empty the bin, will you?” right? And I said, “Oh, do I have to?” And I was watching something, it was like “Why Don’t You?” or something like that on the telly.
Is this what started your tea bag and banana skin collection?
Right, so it was like, do you know in the summer holidays where you’d have dead good telly in the morning--

I was, like, loving that, I was watching that. My dad said, “Empty the bin.” I said, “Aww, 'The Monkees’ are on in a minute.” He said, “Just empty the bin.” So I emptied it and just put it near the door. He said, “Don’t leave it there!” He said, “Stick it near the bins in the garden!” I said, “I’ll put it there later.” He said, “No, do it now!”
Right? So I was like, “Oh, if I miss the beginning of this, I’ll be livid.”

Right? So I picked it up quick, ran out down to the bottom of the garden, slung it in the corner and, sort of, went to turn back to go back in and I had to look again cause they had, like, a little AA truck. They bought me-
It wasn’t brand new, but he’d got it from somewhere. A little AA go-cart, do you know one of them, like, little things- I mean, I was, I was young.
Well, kind of- you know, the plastic ones.
When you’re about, I don’t know, I must have been like five or six or something.
So, I don’t quite follow. That-that, had he sent you out there--
He sent me out with the bin bag--
So I could see what he’d got me. And it wasn’t me birthday or anything, he’d just got it from somewhere.
You’re sure he hadn’t just nicked it and dumped it right out the back?
But, uh, that-that was, like, a genuine, like, “Oh, yeah, smart.”
So I went back in, watched the telly for a bit and then went back out.
Did I tell, did I tell you about my go-cart?
About your dad giving it away.
I don’t- I don’t think I’ve told you this, have I?
Oh, go on. Well, tell it again.
I-I- have I told it on air? I can’t remember. Maybe I just told you it. Um, when I was about eight or nine, I had a go-cart and I loved it. It was one of those that you pressed back and forth--

And I used to come in every day, used to just get changed, run out and it was, um, behind the shed and I used to just go up and down the garden. And one day I came running in and I ran out and I couldn’t see it. And I went up to the back door and my mum was washing up and I went, “Where’s my go-cart?” She went, “Your dad swapped it.”

Yeah. With his mate, Jimmy, in the pub. He went- I said, “Oh.” She went, “Yeah, he swapped it for a wheelbarrow.” So I went and looked back and there was this wheelbarrow, right, that was obviously just came off a building site.
Covered in concrete. Couldn’t- it was steel. Right, I could hardly move it.
And I went back and I went, “Really?” She went, “Yeah, it’s your wheelbarrow.”
I'm thinking me dad, me dad lost a wheelbarrow that dad.
Yeah. And I used to, used to push that up and down and it wasn’t the same and--
You used to push the wheelbarrow up and down?
No, I was just trying to, sort of, keep meself amused. But anyway, that summer, I went on holiday and, uh, I went to Bogner with my mum and nan. Um--

Yeah, yeah. And I was sort of out, out by the caravan and, um, I made friends with this, this kid and he’d hired a go-cart from the, the caravan center, right. And I remember he was going ‘round in it and, uh, it was great and I said, and I said, “I’ve got a go-cart.” and the caravan window opened and my mum said, “Don’t lie.”
Did you ever really forgive him for that? I’d never forgiven my dad if he’d swapped a go-cart for a wheelbarrow.
I just thought it’s par for the course. You know what I mean?
Sure. Did you used to rush home, change and--
Get into that, sort of, gardener’s gear?
Straight into your hard hat and Dungarees.
I’d go, “Mum, any bricks need moving?”
Still, that was your happiest day.
That’s-that’s the one that sprang to mind.
And my unhappiest. See how go-carts can be good or bad?
Does that make you think, Karl? That the go-cart is, you know, is good and evil.
Oh brilliant, what adverts you got!?
Electric Soft Parade, “Same Way Everyday” on XFM 104.9. I’m Ricky Gervais.
Rick I, um, I only had one thing I had to do all week, okay?
I only had- I was- all week, I was so excited about getting up, Friday morning, phoning, getting Bruce Springsteen tickets.
The Boss is playing in, uh--
In October and basically got up too late.
It had sold out, it had sold out, but I started calling about twelve-thirty, it had sold out. I trolled the ‘net, I trolled, uh, all the phone lines--
Yeah, but a lot of- some of those buys are bulk buys for selling on, aren’t they? They’re not all individual--
This is the problem. This is the problem. I mean, I don’t know how many people they can fit in Wembley Arena, but sold it out by twelve-thirty and that’s popular.

I was so gutted. It was all I had to do. I was so looking forward to it. I phoned up one of those, like, quite dodgy phony ticket agencies. Do you know how much he was offering- you know that they’re like, forty-five quid to buy. He said the starting price is two hundred and twenty-five quid. I mean, that to me is like a ticket tout, like, illegal ticket tout.
Are they allowed to do that?
I don’t know, it’s crazy. I was so angry.
They could make- they’d have to say their booking fee was a hundred and fifty pounds.

Exactly. So I- but now I’m just, I'm just, like, desperate. I don’t know what to do. I’m just wondering if I could abuse our position on the radio and just try and scrounge them from anyone who’s listening.
No, I mean anyone who’s listening, who’s got the power to get them, you know, or-or--
This is-this is exactly what it is, Rick, yeah. Yeah, I was going to try and dress it up--
That ticket tout’s after you, as well, for dissing him.
Shut up. [email protected] If there’s anything you can do to get me a ticket- I’m willing to pay for it, um, up to the price of forty-five quid.
Yeah. Well, second hand. Thirty! You don’t, you don’t want to throw your money around, Steve.
I’ll give twenty-five quid, c’mon. Don’t you know who I am?
But, um, but that- do you know what I mean? Cause I asked Karl if he could sort it out. He’s done nothing, he’s achieved nothing.
So I’m just desperate, I’m in a desperate situation and I don’t quite know what to do.

I’ll tell you this, though, Karl. Don’t bother doing favors for him cause he’s not grateful. He-he-he- you give him something and he goes, “Right, does this mean I have to give you something back?” and I go, “Well, no.” and he goes, “Good!”
Well, I got you Cure tickets and you did nothing but whinge about it.
Yeah, it was rubbish, that gig.

It was rubbish. I went along to that gig, it was a balmy summer’s night. The Cure, as far as I’m concerned, owe me a balmy summer’s night cause I wasted it. Hour and a half they played for. They played four hits. I don’t want to hear their dirge from, like, some dodgy album from, like, 1984. I’m not interested! Play the hits; “Boys Don’t Cry”, “Love Cats”, blah, blah, blah, blah, blah. Instead, I got nothing! I was so angry. I was, I was just- oh, man I was angry.
You were probably angry at Karl, weren’t you?
I was angry at Karl for wasting my time, getting me the tickets--
Yeah, you know what I mean, Karl?
If I had paid for it, I would have been absolutely livid.
Are you getting- you getting to see what sort of bloke Steve Merchant is?
No, it’s the point. Do you not agree, though, that if you’re going to see a band like The Cure on a summer’s night--
Hyde Park, you do not want to hear some obscure B-sides and album tracks.
But that- that’s what- that was the great thing about, um, when I saw Bowie at the BBC. He played--
What? When did you see Bowie?
Oh, what, your showbiz friend Jonathan Ross?
What was this? Was that that TV thing he did?
You went to that? You haven’t told me about this.
Well, you were away, I think.
No, I wasn’t. Cause I watched it on TV.
Yeah. And then, then I went onto his show on the Saturday.
Yeah, cause I was- Jonathan said, “Oh, I need someone to come in.” Yeah and I went onto the radio show.
So you were hanging out with Bowie?
Go on. Who else was there?
Should I go through my favorite artists and you just name ‘em and see- if they were there, just let me know.
No, but it was amazing, right? Cause he started- he-he played, um, uh, just doing--

Cause it was that, it was the “Meltdown” thing and he did, uh, “Be My Wife”, which was great. Then he started doing “Fame”, right, and they had been talking about “Ziggy” in the, um, in the interview. He was going, “Oh, everyone always goes ‘Ziggy’. Would you just stop it?” And it was sort of, like, got to a point where he was going, “Oh-” and it was really funny and, uh, uh, but Jonathan’s got a favorite phase with that. And then he started playing, um, “Fame” and it was really good and he just went, “Stop this, stop this. This isn’t- uh, this, uh…let’s do ‘Ziggy.’” And I--

My spine tingled. I welled up- and “Ziggy Stardust” and I’ll tell you what, it sounded like the album version. And he’s got an amazing ballad and it was- and I love it when they do that. I hate it when they- just cause they’ve been going for twenty-five years, they start changing it--

Sorry, I can’t believe that you went to this, that you knew you were going to this and you never asked me. You never asked Jonathan if you could get me in. I mean, seriously, I- I mean, you know how much that would have meant to me.

Yeah, but it was very tight. Apparently- I-I know, but- very, very, it was very, sort of- apparently, Richard, uh, Branson couldn’t get in. There was a queue, so I was like special- it was, it was me, me and Jane went, um, uh, David Baddiel and, uh, Frank Skinner--
Oh, what; suddenly your new showbiz friends of yours, are they?
No! No, I mean, they- I’m rubbing it in Steve. I don’t--
But you might not have liked it. You might have complained like Karl with The Cure and you-you-you’d turn your back on it.
That was rubbish, though. That was rubbish.
Well, you might not have liked what David did, you know, I--

I’ll tell you this. Seriously, if I find out that you do- that you’ve gone to some secret gig or something in the future and I find out- Seriously, that’s it. There’s no more “Office”, there’s no more--
No, I’m not joking. I’m not mucking around, cause that, to me, is like- that’s what friendship is. That’s like textbook example of friendship.
No, I just think that’s really awful.
No, you were off. You were away.
I wasn’t away! Don’t try and fool me!
I wouldn’t have been away. If I was away, I wouldn’t have been away if you had told me that was happening.
You were asleep. You were asleep.
I-I‘m-I‘m- Seriously, I’m… we can joke about it, but I’m really angry about this.
There’s a secret, right, there's a secret- Apparently there’s a secret Bruce Springsteen gig that’s been planned--
Are you? I- If you, seriously--
Seriously, if I find out that you’re at that, I will- I mean--
Play a record so I can shout expletives at Ricky Gervais.
What do you want to play?
I- Oh.. I’ll tell you what, lovely little bit of Electronic.
Just a coo- uh, calm and sooth me. I’m just- Seriously, I’m not joking. That really winds me up. That really winds me up.
Electronic, “Getting Away With It”. Nice to hear that again, Rick.
Yeah, lovely. Love all that, love all that.
You’ve got your result, haven’t ya?

Steve, Steve demands a lot of hard work here.

You’d have probably have, uh, sorted me right out. Yeah, but no, I mean- we-we, joking aside, it is quite serious. And, um, and as I said, I don’t want to pay out the nose for ‘em. I’m willing to go up to, sort of, forty-seven pounds.

If he could go to the front of the queue.
Oh, man. That was so embarrassing.

I tried to bribe- did I tell you that, Karl? I tried to bribe the, uh, bouncer. He was coming out, he was just- he thought he was really- he thought he was in, sort of, he was- he was like the bouncer at The Met Club or The Met Bar, or something.
He was choos- no that wasn’t it. He was picking people off, right?

That was it, he was picking people. He was going, “You, you can come in, you can come in.” I got chatting up a couple of girls. And two pou- cause the problem I had was, I didn’t want to go straight to, like, a tenner.
Because if he had accepted seven, I didn’t want to be down.
I didn’t want to waste the money.
No. You were right Steve. You were right, Steve.

It was the term- is that frugal? What is the term for that; thrifty? I know, um--
No, I- but I’m resenting this because you are trying to create this kind of, this lies, this myth that I’m somehow, you know, like that I’m somehow--
Cheap with my money. Or that I’m not a great lover.
You know what I mean? And that sort of- that I’m, like- it’s annoying me.
Oh, dear. Um, Karl, you went to, uh, Habitat this week, didn’t you?
You’re not going to believe this, Steve.

Was in Habitat, there was only one-one sat on the sofa. Not one of the lads, but one of the, one of the--
Wha- is that like- when you say big headed lad, is he like Frank Sidebottom big head? I mean, is it- what is it?
I don’t know- this is why I, you know, it’s nice to--
Do you think, maybe, it’s medical--
If there’s a doctor listening, right?

Probably- you see, it’s weird how it’s always kids who I see with it, so I’m wondering whether--
And when they get older, it works out alright.
Like jumpers. My mum used to get me jumpers a size too big so they would last a year.
So I’m just wondering if it’s the same thing.
So how old are these, generally? Are they about, like, adults?
When I was at school there, I was probably about like seven and this kid--
And do they have any kind of apparatus to, sort of, keep their head from, kind of, you know, not tipping them over or, sort of, standing up--
I’m just worried that their head’s getting too heavy for their body, or something and their--
No, they- I mean, it’s not that big.
It’s, uh, it’s just not right. You kinda go, you-you sort of do a bit of a double take.
Like the fringe isn’t, sort of, you know, just above their eyes. It was quite high up.
And is this something that repulses you, slightly? Do you get--
No, no, no. That’s- that would be cruel.
But it’s not cruel to discuss it on the radio.
So- and I would just like to know what it is. If it’s like a… like a water on the head type thing, right?
A water on the head type thing?
But yeah. If anyone knows what it is--
So, what time are we doing--

Are you sure it wasn’t perspective? Are you sure he wasn’t, sort of, um, sort of, leaning forward and he was really tall so the top of the head looked quite big, but then it went in to a little body, but really his body was a lot further away?

Do you know how you always, like, um--
You’re going on about, uh, there’s no ghosts and stuff.

Someone here who I work with--
Right? I’m not going to say who they are cause it doesn’t matter. But they were eating, uh, space cake. Right?
What do you mean by that, Karl? Explain.

A dope brownie or whatever, yeah.
So-so-so-something with cannabis in it. Is that what you’re saying?
I think it’s something stronger than that, innit? I don’t know, but anyway, he was having this space cake and--
You better give me the name now, Karl, cause I’ve got to report ‘em.
It’s only- no, no, no, no, cause it is still--

So listen, right? He’s at a party, right, with his mates and they’re listening to, um, the, uh, Starsailor album.
Right? And, uh, sat there and he’s had some of this cake--
And, uh, he’s listening to the album and his mates sat across the way talking to someone else.
And he thinks to himself, “This track's going on a bit.”
And his mate, across the way, who was talking to someone else--
Heard him say it and he goes--
See, usually at this point, I’d say, “Had this bloke taken drugs?” but you started the story--
But since- he- if he, if he was here now--
Right, you would say, “Yeah. No, I think- I know it sounds mental--
“But it happened.” And it wasn’t just the one question, it wasn’t just like, “Oh, this track’s a bit long, innit?” “Yeah, it is.”
It was a whole conversation with the guy.
Sorry, I-I just want to clarify. You mean, he had the whole conversation telepathically?
Right. He didn’t just shout across the room.
And they recently met up and they, like, sat there and tried to, like, work out what happened and--

Yeah. Why did they meet up? Couldn’t they have just, like, in their own homes?
Just stay at home and do it.
Do they, do they have to have that cake before they start having their conversation? “Hold on. Wait a minute, lads. Why are we using our lips?”
“This is using way too many- oh, take- there we go, mmm.”

Right and he did thirty-two blinks.

Neil Young, “After the Goldrush.” So go on, Karl. Sorry. Go on, Karl.

“We’re going to, uh, going to cut your head off. Um, you know, you’ve got to, got to show people that you can’t be doing what you’ve been doing.”
When you said a couple years ago, you mean, maybe, sort of--

And, uh, so he said, “Yeah, fair enough.”
Yeah, imagine that. All those years.
“Could we take your head off?” “Well, fair enough.”
Yeah, exactly. Simon Schama’s "History of Britain".
Yeah, yeah. Oh, and even before that, which was Yonks.
Before, when  it was all mental and different.
So he’s having his head cut off and he’s- but he’s resigned to it.
No, it’s-it’s the day before, he’s kind of got it into his head now that, “I’m not going to have me head, um, much longer.”
He said, uh, “I wonder how long, like, the body can stay alive.”
“Without the head on it.” Right? So they were like, “Ooh, I dunno.”
“No, wait a minute. I’ve got an interesting scientific experiment, jailor.” “Well, fair enough.”
So, uh, he said, “What I want to do-” Right? He said, um, you know, “Surely, it’s me last right, you know, I’m going to be, I'm going to be dead tomorrow. So, um--”
He didn’t draw it out this long, did he?

Yeah, he said, “Let’s-let’s-let’s-let’s test this out, you know. It’s a- do us a favour, you know." He said, "It’s me last day. Um, what I want you to do is- you going to cut me head off. Let’s put a white line on the floor.”

“And see if, you know-” Cause there’s no point asking how far it can, sort of, walk without an head if there isn’t a line cause you-you don’t know what to count, do you know what I mean? If it’s just- if he loses his head and he’s running around all over the place, you can’t really count--
Yeah. It’s not impressive enough, yeah.
So, so they said, “Let’s make a white line.”
Yeah. Who said this; he did or they did?
I think they started to join in with him and say, “Well, let’s make this--”
Have they got Norris McWhirter down?
So they said, “Let us get this white line and, uh--”
“We’ll-we’ll do this, do this tomorrow.” He said, “Alright, then. I’ll see ya in the morning.”
“See you in the morning! Oh, see you in the morning. Night-night, sleep tight.”
I love the fact that Karl knows exactly what was said.
He doesn’t know the story or what order it’s in or when it was.
But he knows exactly what was said.
Or who said what, but he knows the interviews of- “Alright then. See you in the morning. Mwah, mwah. Bye, kissy, kissy, kissy.”
“Oh, I’m not like that.” “Oh, you joker.”

So, uh, so they go, “Right, you ready, then?” And he said, “Aye, go on.” And they cut his head off and… the body walked thirty-two steps without a head.
Did it get as far as the white- it walked along the white line, did it?
Yeah, he stayed along the white line, did thirty-two steps and then started to stumble a bit and it just fell over.
But it was a test that your body can still keep alive for a little bit.
What-what do you reckon you can do then without a head? How many steps?
It would- yeah. You could not distinctly take thirty-two steps.
Ohh. Is the doctor still on the line? The fella that bought six parrots and, uh… No, you couldn’t walk thirty-two steps.
Right, so you don’t believe that--
A beheaded man doing a bit of line dancing.
Right, you don’t believe that, but something that you do believe that a cockroach can live a week without a head.
It can. Slightly different. Slightly different kettle of fish, there.
Well, mmm. Insect to, uh, human is what I’m thinking. That difference.
Do you know that a snake has a heart and lungs and kidneys and stuff.
You making it as if,like it’s a totally different, like--
I am. I am making that. I mean, call me old-fashioned--
Rick, do you know what you’re talking about, there?
I don’t want you embarrassing yourself, Rick.

Yeah. I am suggesting they’re totally different beings, yeah. That is- yeah. Now, um, Karl, th-th-the cockroach is-is a very different thing. The interesting thing there is that it lives, it lives without it’s head cause a lot of it’s on, uh, uh, uh- there’s- Some of ‘em are phototrophic, chemotrophic, some of ‘em just literally have, uh, irritation and muscle memory. I mean, they do have a central nervous system, but it-it-it-it’s very different. So if you lose the head, it bypasses a lot of that anyway. All this is running around. The reason they die is cause they can’t take on water. But it’s very different to a man, right, having consciousness and then losing that and the body still going, “Oh, I remember- I think I remember what I was going to do here--”
Yeah. “So I’ve got to walk along the line.”
“I’m going to carefully walk thirty-two steps along this white line.” I imagine him just looking down going, “Oh, missed a bit.”
Um, maybe the head was in the corner going, “Left!”
Well, let’s just put it out. I mean, if-if-if anyone listening is, uh, has maybe had a relative--
Beheaded, maybe in a horrendous car accident, but they got up. Maybe they-they went for a walk, uh, they, you know, they-they-they had a little chat before they passed on.

But why do cockroaches do that? Why, whoever made ‘em, went--
